Hi Everyone,
Alexis will be performing on June 20th with her colleague Terrence Fay, a talented Trombone player and Tenor singer. She's very enthusiastic about this concert, and it should be an excellent performance. Below are more details from her facebook posting. Hope to see you there!
-Neil
203-645-2008


Terrence is the assistant principal trombone of the New Haven Symphony Orchestra! When he's not playing trombone, he sings throughout CT! Here's a little bio for him...
Terrence B. Fay, a native of Wantagh, New York, began singing professionally in 1999, accepting a job with the choir of Christ Church, New Haven, a position which he held for five years, during which time, he went on to sing with such groups as the Choir of Men and Boys at Trinity on the Green, New Haven, the Marquand Chapel Choir at the Yale Divinity School, the choir of St. Mary’s, New Haven, MidAmerica Productions, Inc., and in 2003, became a member of the Grammy-award winning choir, Gaudeamus. He has also performed as soloist with the choirs of Trinity Episcopal Church, Torrington and St. John’s Lutheran Church, Stamford. Terrence is currently a member of the choirs of St. John the Evangelist, Stamford, and St. Mary’s Church, Norwalk.
Terrence makes much of his living, however, as a trombonist, having studied trombone performance at the Juilliard School, the Yale School of Music, and the Royal Academy of Music, London. He is currently the assistant principal trombonist of the New Haven Symphony Orchestra and principal trombonist of the New Britain Symphony Orchestra. He has also performed with the Rhode Island Philharmonic, Eastern Connecticut and Wallingford Symphonies, and the Wisconsin and Moscow State Chamber Orchestras, among others.
Terrence is currently on faculty at the Educational Center for the Arts, Neighborhood Music School, Choate Rosemary Hall, and the Universities of New Haven and Bridgeport.


Parlez-vous francais?

Terrence B. Fay, tenor and trombone and Alexis Zingale, piano, in songs of Faure and Duparc, and works of Jongen, Saint-Saens and more.

Saint-Saens: Cavatine

Rachmaninoff: Elegy (arr. Alessi)

Duparc: Chanson Triste, L'Invitation au Voyage, Phidylé

Faure: Automne, Sylvie, Ici Bas, Le Secret, Les Berceaux

Massenet: Meditation from "Thais"

Jongen: Aria and Polonaise

This is a program that will appeal to a lot of tastes, even if you're new to classical music!
There will be hanging out for food and drinks afterward at an establishment yet to be chosen...
